subject: Economics
title: Nudging Retirement Savings: The Power of Defaults
description: A micro-lesson that makes Nudging Retirement Savings: The Power of Defaults usable.

hook.text: When companies auto-enroll employees in 401(k) plans, participation jumps from 49% to 86%.

buildup.text: Richard Thaler showed that people intend to save but procrastinate.

discovery.text: The Save More Tomorrow program lets workers commit future raises to savings. They never feel a pay cut.

twist.text: Critics say nudges are manipulation. Thaler argues every system has a default â€” why not pick the one that helps people?

climax.text: Defaults prove that how you present a choice matters as much as the choice itself. Architecture shapes outcomes.

punchline.text: The best retirement plan is the one you never have to choose.

quiz.question: What happens when companies auto-enroll employees in 401(k) plans?
